intro: Acaciella costaricensis, commonly known as the Costa Rican acacia, is a shrub native to Central America, particularly Costa Rica. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which is characterized by its pod fruits and nitrogen-fixing abilities. The plant has compound leaves with small, oval-shaped leaflets and produces yellow or orange flowers. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often found in dry forests and disturbed areas. Due to its ecological importance and ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaciella costaricensis is primarily native to Central America, specifically Costa Rica and Panama. It is commonly found in lowland tropical dry forests and secondary growth areas. This plant thrives in regions with a warm, humid climate and well-drained soils. It is often associated with disturbed habitats and can be found near human settlements. Its distribution is limited to specific ecological zones within these countries.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaciella costaricensis was mainly introduced to urban and roadside environments in Central America and the Caribbean. It is commonly found in disturbed soils and along transportation corridors. The plant is valued for its rapid growth and ability to stabilize soil. However, it has also been reported as an invasive species in some regions. Its distribution is expanding due to human activity and climate change.
